text: Hey, wakey wakey. If you've yet to play
the fantastic Pinocchio inspired
soulslike lies of pee, then its first
DLC expansion, Overture, is filled with
finely polished reasons to do so. I'm
not sure what's going on, but we better
check things out. Though it's whittleled
from the same timber and sticks very
closely to the original stage
directions, this 12-hour encore has
plenty of new and still deeply
depressing areas to
explore, some additional tools to carve
baddies into kindling
with, and more impressively menacing
bosses to drop the curtain on.
Plus, it does a great job fleshing out
an already awesome story by tugging on a
few strings that were left dangling in
the base game and landing some
surprising ventrilla twists, renewing my
appreciation for just how well this
fibfilled tale made me care about its
characters. You belong to me now.
I was happy to put my elongated nose
back to the hacken slash grindstone of
this top puppeteer Soulslike, which left
me more excited than ever for a proper
sequel. If you're just joining us after
the intermission, Lies of PE is one of
the better Souls likes to take the stage
in a very crowded genre. Aside from its
unique weapon crafting system, it didn't
introduce many new ideas to shine a
spotlight on, but the stuff it borrowed
is all done extremely
well. Overture doesn't try to fix what
isn't broken, adding a dozen hours of
daunting challenges in a timetraveling
prequel that throws you back to the
events preceding the main story. At
roughly a third of the size of the
original game, this DLC feels pretty
massive. Following a similar, albeit
much more modest, model as Elden Ring's
Shadow of the Air Tree DLC by greatly
expanding the amount of areas,
bosses, and loot to collect.
It does that while introducing an
interesting second act to the story to
boot. So, there is enough meat on these
wooden bones for me to remember how much
I adored this devious adventure in the
first place. So, who is this handsome
guest standing before me?
With a mostly new cast of characters,
Overture could almost be enjoyed as a
standalone adventure were it not only
accessible once you're most of the way
through the main story. Plus, it leans
pretty heavily into existing lore where
a lot of the payoff requires you to know
how it all ends. Too many stalkers were
lost to that evil murderous puppet. But
still, as someone who hasn't revisited
Lies of Peace since launch, I didn't
feel at all lost, and it does a great
job reintroducing you to the calamitous
city of mechanical puppets and diseased
creatures that is Krat.
This new tall tale is every bit as
heartbreaking and bleak as I'd expect
with some interesting twists and turns
that fill in existing gaps in unexpected
ways and offer some very satisfying
answers to questions I was left
pondering over a year
ago. It's also got some of the most epic
and sometimes stomach churning moments
I've seen in a game in a long time. I
kind of forgot how full anime this thing
really goes at times, and that's
definitely a good thing in my
book. The main attractions in Overture
are the super weird new places you'll
visit and the evil monsters you'll
murder along the way. During one early
area, you'll walk through a zoo and get
attacked by all manner of deranged
animal, from apes to
elephants to this giant
alligator. In another section, you'll
run across a perilous lake of ice that
falls apart under your feet while
pirate-like puppets attempt to send you
plunging into Davy Jones's locker with a
cannon. There's quite a bit of variety,
and it's especially cool to see the
number of new enemies that have been
added to the mix, like undead fish that
leap out of the water and try to gobble
you up while flopping
about. This DLC really wants you to kill
animals, if you couldn't tell.
That said, interesting new areas are
also offset somewhat by curiously
retread ground, including this carnival
section that feels awfully familiar to
the parade themed spaces and enemies
we've already seen
before. There's also plenty of rehashed
enemies, like these standard psychotic
humanoid puppets and undead dogs that
have way more teeth than I'm comfortable
with.
One of the standout parts of Overture is
its new bosses, which are extremely
original, mostly challenging, and serve
as exciting climaxes after the slower
leadups of slashing through chump
minions and reading private documents
you find lying around. You nosy little
mannequin,
you. I'll avoid spoiling as many as I
can, but there's a good mix of
absolutely massive ugly monsters
wielding such enormous weapons that it's
completely insane that you can parry
them with your tiny
sword and fastmoving humanoid enemies
who dodge around and cross blades with
you in a contest of reflexes and pattern
recognition. Scream for my pleasure. The
final boss in particular, who has some
of the most hilariously convoluted
attacks Lies of P has ever concocted, is
especially fun to learn and provided a
satisfying conclusion and final skill
check that made me feel like I'd really
earned that ending. None of these
encounters were as difficult as I
remember some of the hardest fights in
the base game being, but that's
partially because they were better
balanced in general, so I had more fun
dying and learning their ins and outs
with better consistency.
It's also possible I've just gotten
better at Souls likes since I've
reviewed about 50 of them in the past
few years, from Lords of the Fallen to
Another Crabs Treasure. But I definitely
enjoyed what felt like a more
predictable level of challenge all
around. Though there's plenty of cool
new sites to see and things to kill in
Overture, not much at all has changed
with the actual momentto- moment
gameplay. There are at least a handful
of interesting new weapons to use, like
these deadly hand claws that are a
really great option for dexterity
focused
builds, as well as some new amulets to
augment your build with, but nothing
that's outside of what you'd expect to
find in the base game. And when it comes
to things like actual combat strategy or
exploration, this add-on is largely just
more lies a pee. That's definitely a
good thing, but it does mean I still
have all the same criticisms as before.
The sections that lead up to each boss
fight are still significantly easier
than those eventual encounters, and the
stiff combat system locks you into a
pretty specific Bloodborne-like play
style compared to the RPG inspired
nature of other Souls likes that give
you more freedom. It's not a huge deal
that these issues haven't really been
ironed out, but what is a little
disappointing is how Overture plays it
fairly safe when it comes to new
mechanics. It only introduces one in the
form of a fresh upgrade tree system that
let you further improve and customize
passive benefits, some of which increase
the damage you deal or make you more
likely to survive a barrage of attacks
from a boss. This system is certainly
neat, but it mostly feels like an
extension of the existing upgrade system
that just adds more runway to leveling
up. There aren't any major shakeups to
the sorts of things you'll be doing as
you butcher your way through Crot, so
it's a good thing doing so is as fun as
ever. Overture is a prequel DLC that
simply provides more Lies of P, and
that's an extremely good thing. The new
areas are largely a breath of fresh air,
and the added enemy types inject even
more variety into a world that was
already pretty well stocked with things
trying their absolute best to murder
your puppet face.
There isn't much in the way of
surprising ideas or interesting new
mechanics, but having a fresh set of
formidable bosses to take down is
compelling enough in its own right, with
some of them standing amongst the most
exciting encounters, merry and
yet. Couple those with a fully featured
story that's every bit as satisfying as
the original, and this is one creepy
puppet show I'm glad to revisit.
For more, check out our reviews of Elden
Ring Night Reign or Game of Thrones:
King's Road. And for everything else,
stick with
IGN. That
bastard. I'll kill him.
